metadata.titleEn: Ground observation dataset of corn biomass, vegetation coverage, leaf area index and plant height at Daman station in the middle reaches of Heihe River (growth period in 2020)
metadata.description: This dataset is a continuous ground observation data of vegetation coverage (%), biomass (g/plant), leaf area index (LAI) and plant height (cm) of seed corn during the growing period in 2020 at Daman Station ( 38.85551N,100.37223E)in the middle reaches of the Heihe River. Ground observation was carried out in three sample plots.  Biomass observation included fresh and dry aboveground biomass, fresh and dry underground biomass (fresh and dry root weight), vegetation coverage was observed by digital camera, leaf area index was observed by LAI 2200, and plant height was observed by tape measure. The observation period was from May 31 to September 22, 2020. Observation parameters were observed every 5 days before July 31 and every 10 days thereafter, and a total of 19 observations were carried out during the whole growing period. The dataset can provide data basis for inversion and validation of surface vegetation parameters.
metadata.instructions: Observation data are stored in Excel form. The file name is yyyy.xlsm, where yyyy stands for year.

background: Crop biomass is one of the most important biophysical indicators of crop growth. The accurate and efficient estimation of the regional crop biomass at different growth stages is of great importance in guiding crop management decision making, such as in effective fertilization, water irrigation, weeding, and pest and disease management. In addition, as an important aspect of biomass energy, the accurate estimation of crop biomass contributes to the rational and effective utilization of biomass energy. Moreover, effective estimates of crop biomass during the growing season could play a key role in crop yield prediction. The traditional crop biomass estimation method is mainly based on field measurements, which include destructive field sampling, laboratory drying and weighting. The traditional methods are relatively accurate, but they are labor intensive and time consuming. Moreover, the sparse nature of space makes it impossible to provide a comprehensive understanding at regional or larger scales. Thus, it is impossible to acquire the regional crop biomass via ground measurements alone. The satellite remote sensing technique is a unique and useful method for crop biomass monitoring in a repeatable manner due to the valuable information it provides on vegetation parameters, high spatial coverage and long time series, which effectively compensates for the deficiency of traditional biomass estimation methods. Previous studies have revealed that remote sensing is a reliable and effective technique to obtain biophysical and biochemical crop information.
research objective: In this paper, four machine learning models, namely random forest (RF), support vector machine (SVM), artificial neural network (ANN), and extreme gradient boosting (XGBoost) were adopted to estimate the seasonal corn biomass based on field observation data and moderate resolution imaging spectroradiometer (MODIS) reflectance data from 2012 to 2019 in the middle reaches of the Heihe River basin, China.
challenges: This is currently one of the major challenges for agricultural researchers and farm managers.
methods: In this study, the corn biomass was estimated based on daily MODIS datasets with a 500 m spatial resolution combined with long-term ground observation data in the middle reaches of the Heihe River Basin, and four machine learning algorithms, namely RF, SVM, ANN, and XGBoost, were adopted to predict the biomass. Large, relatively homogeneous areas, which mainly functioned as corn growing areas, were selected as the sample sites. According to a field survey of the sample sites, a total of sixteen sites were selected in 2012, and three sites were selected for field measurement purposes every year from 2013 to 2019. One to three plots for each sample site were chosen for further biomass observation, with each plot covering an area of 100 m ×100 m. All selected plants in each plot were collected, and the roots of the corn plants were washed. The fresh weight was measured, after which the plants were transported to the laboratory, chopped into easy-to-dry segments, and dried in an oven at 85°C for 48–72 h until a constant dry biomass was obtained. MODIS MCD43A4 and MOD15A2 products from May to September from 2012 to 2019 were analyzed in this study. The forward feature selection method was implemented to choose the most influential variables, which is an iterative method starting from the condition of no model features. In each iteration, we add a given feature that best improves the model until the addition of a new variable does not further improve the model performance. The RF, SVM, ANN, and XGBoost algorithms were adopted in this study. R software was used to implement the above four machine learning algorithms with the randomForest, kernlab, brnn, and xgboost packages. In this study, the caret package in R software was applied to tune the parameters of the above four machine learning algorithms. The 10-fold cross validation method was implemented to evaluate the performance of the above four machine learning models due to the small number of training samples.
dataset: MODIS MCD43A4 and MOD15A2 products from May to September from 2012 to 2019 were analyzed in this study. A total of sixteen sites were selected in 2012, and three sites were selected for field measurement purposes every year from 2013 to 2019. One to three plots for each sample site were chosen for further biomass observation, with each plot covering an area of 100 m ×100 m.
findings: The results indicated that the corn biomass was suitably estimated (the coefficient of determination (R2) was between 0.72 and 0.78) with the four machine learning models. The XGBoost model performed better than the other three models (R2 = 0.78, root mean squared error (RMSE) = 2.86 t/ha and mean absolute error (MAE) = 1.86 t/ha). Moreover, the RF model was an effective method (R2 = 0.77, RMSE = 2.91 t/ha and MAE = 1.91 t/ha), with a performance comparable to that of the XGBoost model.

Disjunctive.Question: Are machine learning models like RF, SVM, ANN, and XGBoost primarily used in this domain for estimating crop biomass, or are other statistical methods more prevalent?
Disjunctive.Answer: Machine learning models like RF, SVM, ANN, and XGBoost are primarily used in this domain for estimating crop biomass.

Concept Completion.Question: What data collection methods are used for measuring corn biomass in agricultural research?
Concept Completion.Answer: Destructive field sampling, laboratory drying and weighting, digital photography, LAI 2200, tape measures

Concept Completion.Question: When are the observations for corn biomass and related parameters conducted during the growing season?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to estimate crop biomass in agricultural research?
Example.Answer: A data collection method used to estimate crop biomass involves field measurements, which include destructive field sampling, laboratory drying, and weighing. The traditional methods are accurate but labor-intensive and time-consuming.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when estimating regional crop biomass using traditional methods?
Example.Answer: A challenge when estimating regional crop biomass using traditional methods is the sparse nature of data collection, which makes it impossible to provide a comprehensive understanding at regional or larger scales. Ground measurements alone cannot acquire regional crop biomass effectively.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the key characteristics of data collection methods used for measuring crop biomass in agricultural research?
Feature Specification.Answer: destructive sampling, laboratory drying, weighting, digital photography for vegetation cover, LAI 2200 for leaf area index, tape measures for plant height, remote sensing techniques, MODIS reflectance data

Feature Specification.Question: What challenges are associated with acquiring regional crop biomass data using ground measurements alone?
Feature Specification.Answer: labor-intensive, time-consuming, sparse nature of space

Feature Specification.Question: What are the specific properties of datasets used for estimating corn biomass in the middle reaches of the Heihe River Basin?
Feature Specification.Answer: MODIS MCD43A4, MOD15A2, May to September, 100 m × 100 m plots, fresh weight, lab drying, RF, SVM, ANN, XGBoost

Quantification.Question: How many observation sessions were conducted during the corn growing season in the field study?
How many sample sites were selected for field measurement purposes each year from 2013 to 2019?
What is the spatial resolution of the MODIS datasets used for corn biomass estimation?

Definition.Question: What is the role of satellite remote sensing in crop biomass monitoring?
Definition.Answer: Satellite remote sensing is a unique and useful method for crop biomass monitoring in a repeatable manner due to the valuable information it provides on vegetation parameters, high spatial coverage, and long time series, which effectively compensates for the deficiency of traditional biomass estimation methods.

Definition.Question: What is the digital camera photographic method in vegetation cover observation?
Definition.Answer: The digital camera photographic method is a data collection technique used for observing vegetation cover percentage by taking photographs with a digital camera.

Definition.Question: What is the forward feature selection method in machine learning model development?
Definition.Answer: The forward feature selection method is an iterative process used to choose the most influential variables by starting with no model features and adding features that best improve the model until no further improvement is observed.

Comparison.Question: How do ground-based observations for corn biomass estimation compare with remote sensing techniques in terms of accuracy and labor intensity?
Comparison.Answer: Ground-based observations, such as destructive field sampling and laboratory drying, are relatively accurate but labor-intensive and time-consuming. In contrast, remote sensing techniques provide valuable information on vegetation parameters with high spatial coverage and long time series, which effectively compensates for the deficiencies of traditional methods.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences and similarities in the data collection methods used for estimating corn biomass on the ground versus using MODIS datasets?
Comparison.Answer: Ground-based methods involve direct measurements like fresh and dry weight observations and measurements of plant height on sample plots. MODIS datasets, on the other hand, leverage satellite-based reflectance data to provide regional crop biomass estimates. Both methods aim to estimate biomass, but ground-based methods are more direct and localized, while MODIS offers broader coverage and is less labor-intensive.

Interpretation.Question: How do the selected machine learning algorithms infer the relationship between MODIS reflectance data and corn biomass during different growth stages?
Interpretation.Answer: The machine learning algorithms, including random forest (RF), support vector machine (SVM), artificial neural network (ANN), and extreme gradient boosting (XGBoost), use field observation data and MODIS reflectance to estimate corn biomass. They analyze patterns in the data to model the relationship between the observed reflectance and biomass measurements, improving predictions over time through iterative training and feature selection.

Interpretation.Question: What can be inferred about the challenges of using ground-based measurements alone for regional biomass estimation, and how does satellite remote sensing complement these efforts?
Interpretation.Answer: Ground-based measurements are accurate but labor-intensive and not feasible for large-scale regional assessments due to their spatial limitations. Satellite remote sensing, with its high spatial coverage and long time series, complements ground-based efforts by providing comprehensive and continuous data, thus addressing the spatial limitations of ground-based methods and allowing for more complete biomass estimation across larger areas.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the complexity of accurately estimating crop biomass using satellite remote sensing techniques?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Satellite remote sensing techniques provide valuable information on vegetation parameters and offer high spatial coverage and long time series, which are essential for regional crop biomass estimation. However, the complexity arises from the need to effectively compensate for the deficiencies of traditional biomass estimation methods, which are labor-intensive and time-consuming, and the challenge of achieving comprehensive coverage at regional scales solely through ground measurements.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why are traditional crop biomass estimation methods seen as insufficient for regional scale analysis in the context of agricultural research?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Traditional crop biomass estimation methods, which involve destructive field sampling, laboratory drying, and weighing, are accurate but labor-intensive and time-consuming. Their sparse nature and the inability to cover larger spatial scales make them insufficient for regional analysis. Thus, they cannot provide a comprehensive understanding at regional or larger scales, necessitating the use of satellite remote sensing techniques for more extensive and efficient monitoring.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the underlying reasons for using machine learning models in estimating crop biomass based on remote sensing data?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Machine learning models, such as RF, SVM, ANN, and XGBoost, are used to estimate crop biomass because they can effectively handle the integration of field observation data with remote sensing data. These models are capable of analyzing complex patterns and relationships within the data, improving the accuracy of biomass estimates by utilizing influential variables selected through methods like forward feature selection. This approach compensates for the limitations of traditional methods by providing reliable, scalable solutions for biomass estimation.

Causal Consequence.Question: What outcomes might result from using machine learning models to predict crop biomass instead of traditional methods?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using machine learning models to predict crop biomass can lead to more efficient and potentially more accurate estimations compared to traditional methods. Machine learning allows for the integration of large datasets such as MODIS reflectance data, and models like XGBoost and RF have shown high performance in estimating biomass, thus supporting more informed crop management decisions.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to gather ground observation data in conjunction with satellite remote sensing data for estimating crop biomass in agricultural research?
Goal Orientation.Answer: It is important because traditional methods based on field measurements are labor intensive and time-consuming, while satellite remote sensing provides valuable information on vegetation parameters with high spatial coverage and long time series, effectively compensating for the deficiencies of traditional methods and allowing for a more comprehensive regional understanding.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can machine learning models be utilized to estimate crop biomass using both field observation data and remote sensing datasets?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Machine learning models like random forest, support vector machine, artificial neural network, and extreme gradient boosting can be applied to estimate crop biomass by integrating field observation data with remote sensing datasets such as MODIS reflectance data. The process involves selecting sample sites, collecting biomass data, extracting relevant features, and tuning model parameters using techniques like forward feature selection and cross-validation.

Enablement.Question: What data collection methods enable accurate estimation of crop biomass in agricultural research?
Enablement.Answer: Accurate estimation of crop biomass can be enabled by combining traditional field measurements, such as destructive field sampling, with satellite remote sensing techniques that provide high spatial coverage and long time series data.

Enablement.Question: What datasets enable comprehensive understanding of regional crop biomass over large spatial scales?
Enablement.Answer: Datasets such as MODIS MCD43A4 and MOD15A2 products enable a comprehensive understanding of regional crop biomass over large spatial scales by providing valuable vegetation parameters from 2012 to 2019, which can be supplemented with field measurements from selected sites.

Expectation.Question: Why might traditional field measurement methods for crop biomass estimation be expected to face challenges in providing comprehensive data at regional scales?
Expectation.Answer: Traditional field measurement methods are labor-intensive, time-consuming, and limited by the sparse nature of spatial coverage, making it impossible to acquire comprehensive regional data through ground measurements alone.

Expectation.Question: Why might remote sensing techniques be expected to improve the estimation of crop biomass compared to traditional methods?
Expectation.Answer: Remote sensing techniques provide valuable information on vegetation parameters with high spatial coverage and long time series, effectively compensating for the limitations of traditional biomass estimation methods.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways could the current dataset collection methods be expanded or refined to improve the accuracy of crop biomass estimation?
Judgmental.Answer: Expanding dataset collection methods could involve increasing the frequency and spatial resolution of remote sensing data, incorporating additional biophysical parameters, and exploring new sensors or technologies. Refinements might include optimizing the sampling strategy, improving data preprocessing techniques, and adopting advanced machine learning models that better account for variability in environmental conditions.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how different data collection methods impact the accuracy and efficiency of crop biomass estimation.
Assertion.Answer: Traditional methods like field measurements offer high accuracy but are labor-intensive and time-consuming, whereas satellite remote sensing provides a repeatable and large-scale approach that compensates for the limitations of ground measurements.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges that arise in collecting and analyzing long-term ground observation data for crop biomass estimation.
Assertion.Answer: Challenges include the labor-intensive nature of traditional field measurements, the difficulty in covering large or regional scales through ground methods alone, and the need for integrating satellite data to gain comprehensive insights.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the potential of using satellite remote sensing techniques to enhance data collection methods for estimating crop biomass in agricultural research.
Request/Directive.Answer: Satellite remote sensing techniques provide a unique and useful method for crop biomass monitoring due to their high spatial coverage and long time series, which effectively compensate for the deficiencies of traditional biomass estimation methods such as destructive field sampling and laboratory processing.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges associated with traditional field-based crop biomass estimation methods and how machine learning models can address these challenges.
Request/Directive.Answer: Traditional field-based biomass estimation methods are labor-intensive, time-consuming, and cannot provide a comprehensive understanding at regional or larger scales. Machine learning models, like RF, SVM, ANN, and XGBoost, can estimate crop biomass more efficiently by utilizing field observation data in combination with satellite data, thus providing more comprehensive and scalable solutions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify potential datasets that could be integrated with existing field observation data to improve the estimation of crop biomass using machine learning models.
Request/Directive.Answer: MODIS datasets, specifically MCD43A4 and MOD15A2 products, from May to September, have been effectively used in combination with ground observation data to estimate crop biomass. These datasets can be integrated into machine learning models to enhance the estimation process by providing high spatial and temporal resolution data.
